concept.shortdesc: Learn a few tips to make your text easier to translate and less likely to cause translation errors.

section.title: Clarity
section.p:
A text that is easy to understand is usually also easier to translate. To make your writing clearer, use these tips:
Avoid overly long sentences and paragraphs.
Repeat important words to avoid misunderstanding. For example, instead of writing 'If the shaft of your wand breaks, you can get a new one online,' write 'If the shaft of your wand breaks, you can get a new wand online.'
Don't describe more than one action in a sentence unless writing about strictly related actions.
Use words such as "and," "then," "but," "a," "the," "this," and "that" to make your message clear.

section.title: Grammar
section.p:
You can make your text easier to understand by using certain grammatical forms. To make your writing clearer, follow these rules:
Express actions with verbs, not nouns. For example, instead of writing 'Applying excessive force can lead to rupture of your wand,' write 'If you apply excessive force, your wand can break.'
Use active voice.
Split clusters of nouns into smaller logical units. For example, instead of writing 'magic wand cleaning center,' write 'center for cleaning magic wands.'

section.title: Formating
section.p: Search your text for unintended linebreaks and punctuation marks (such as periods in place of commas). CAT tools may misinterpret such characters and split sentences into separate units. This can lead to translation errors and inconsistencies.
Avoid using page breaks and empty lines to set the layout of your document. The same content can have a different volume in different languages.
section.note: When localizing a DITA project, always send the translators your source files rather than the output (such as PDF or HTML files).

concept.shortdesc: Learn about types of content that you may not want to translate.

section.title: Types of non-translatable content
section.p:
While planning the localization of your project, it is important to identify fragments you don't want to translate. These can include the following:
proper names, such as brand names
contact details
code blocks
user interface (UI) text (if the UI has not been localized)
legal text (you may need to handle it separately)
section.note: You can use glossariesLearn the benefits of using glossaries in your localization process. to let translators know which phrases they shouldn't translate.

section.title: UI text
section.p: If your project contains UI terms, it's important to know whether the UI has been translated, and into which languages.
If the UI is not localized, you should let translators know how they should handle UI text. For example, you may want them to follow each UI term with its translation in brackets.

concept.shortdesc: Learn the benefits of using glossaries in your localization process.

section.title: Consistency
section.p: Glossaries are the easiest way to improve the consistency of the translated text. Different translators (or even the same translator at different times) can translate the same term in various ways. Giving them a glossary of approved translations will make their translations more consistent.
section.note: Most CAT tools enable automatic terminology checks to make sure that a translator has used terms from the glossary. But remember that such checks are less reliable in languages where one word can have various grammatical forms.

section.title: Non-translatable text
section.p: Glossaries can also specify text that should not be translated, such as brand names.

section.title: Forbidden terms
section.p: If you don't want a given term to be translated in a particular way, a glossary is also a good place to specify that.
For example, the word "pacemaker" can be translated into Polish as "rozrusznik," but you may want translators to use the less colloquial "stymulator" instead.

section.title: Context
section.p: Glossaries can also provide context for each term, such as its definition.

section.title: Format
section.p: Glossaries (called term bases) can be developed directly in a CAT tool. Most CAT tools have their own term base format, but you can use a universal format called TermBase eXchange (TBX) to move term bases between different tools.
You can also prepare a glossary as a CSV file in a spreadsheet editor and import it into a CAT tool.

concept.shortdesc: Learn a few tips to make your images easier to localize.

section.title: Image format
section.p: If your images contain text that you want to translate, avoid using bitmaps, such as JPG or PNG files. Use SVG files instead. Most CAT tools can translate text contained in SVG files.

section.title: Callouts
section.p: To simplify the localization process, avoid using descriptions within images. Instead, use numbered callouts and explain them under the image.

image.alt: A DITA <fig> element containing an image with two callouts that are explained in a numbered list below the image

section.title: UI screens
section.p: If your documentation contains user interface (UI) screens, it is important to consider whether the UI has been localized. You may need to plan the additional step of capturing UI screens in each target language.

concept.shortdesc: Learn how to structure your project to make localization easier.

section.title: Folder structure
section.p: A logical folder structure will make localization much easier. Do not keep all files in one folder. Instead, create separate folders for your topics, images, and other content.To avoid publishing problems, always store your DITA maps at the same level or above your topics and images.

section.title: Prefixes vs. folders
section.p:
It is common practice to prefix topic names with "c_", "t_", "r_," and "_g" for concepts, tasks, references, and glossary entries, respectively. For example:
c_magic_wand.dita
t_how_to_cast_a_spell.dita
r_wand_specifications.dita
g_wand_shaft.dita
For larger projects, it may be useful to create separate folders for topics of each type. This will make managing the project easier.

image.alt: A flow chart depicting basic project structure with separe folders for images and different types of topics

section.title: Language versions
section.p: To simplify localization, create a separate subfolder for each language version. Each subfolder should have the same structure.

section.title: Files not to be translated
section.p: Some files, such as images and other content, are shared among language versions and don't need to be translated. It's a good idea to keep files you don't want to translate in a separate folder.

concept.shortdesc: Learn how to prepare your DITA code for localization using the xml:lang and translate attributes.

section.title: Setting the language of topics and maps
section.p: It's a best practice to specify the language of your DITA files, even if you're not planning localization. To specify the language and country of a topic or map, set the xml:lang attribute of its root element: <concept id="c_magic" xml:lang="en-US">
section.note: To set an attribute of an element in oXygen XML Editor, select the element, press Alt + Enter, and type the name of the attribute you want to set.

section.title: Identifying content you don't want to translate
section.p: To identify a an element you don't want to translate, set its translate attribute to "no": <codeblock id="codeblock_spells" translate="no"> let spellsLeft = 7; </codeblock>

concept.shortdesc: Learn about attributes and elements used to adjust text sorting and direction.

section.title: Sorting text using the sort-as element
section.p: In languages like English you can easily sort lists by alphabetical order. But it's not that simple in languages such as Japanese and Chinese. This is because the same character can have different pronunciations depending on the meaning.

To specify text you want to use for sorting, add a sort-as element inside a sorted element: <glossentry id="gloss-harry-potter"> <glossterm>ハリー・ポッター</glossterm> <prolog> <sort-as>Harry Potter</sort-as> </prolog> <glossdef></glossdef> </glossentry>

section.title: Sorting index terms using the index-sort-as element
section.p: You can adjust the storting order of index terms by adding the index-sort-as element: <indexterm>ハリー・ポッター <index-sort-as>Harry Potter</index-sort-as> </indexterm>

section.title: Changing text direction using the dir element
section.p: English and many other languages use left-to-right (LTR) script. But there are many languages like Hebrew or Arabic that use right-to-left (RTL) script. To optimize localization, it's a best practice to specify text direction using the dir attribute: <map xml:lang="ar-IQ" dir="rtl">
section.note: To set an attribute of an element in oXygen XML Editor, select the element, press Alt + Enter, and type the name of the attribute you want to set.

concept.shortdesc: Learn best practices for content and keyword referencing to avoid problems with localization.

section.title: Handling conrefs
section.p: You can easily reuse content in DITA with the conref attribute.Example of content referencing in DITA Example of using the conref attribute to reuse content between topics
section.note: To set an attribute of an element in oXygen XML Editor, select the element, press Alt + Enter, and type the name of the attribute you want to set.
section.p:
Improper use of content referencing can lead to translation errors (such as wrong grammatical forms or text not matching the context). To avoid such errors, follow these rules:
Don't use conrefs for incomplete phrases. Instead, use them to reference whole sentences or larger fragments.
Avoid excessive content reuse. This can make it harder for translators to know the context of the translated text.

section.title: Handling keyrefs
section.p: You can reference keywords using the keyref attribute. Keyrefs can be used for standard text or expressions that can change, such as product names.Example of keyword referencing in DITA Example of using keydef and keyword elements in DITA

When used improperly, keyrefs can lead to translation errors. You can minimize such errors by following these tips:
Use keyrefs for terms that do not change their grammatical form, such as product names or UI terms.
Avoid using keyrefs for common nouns.
Treat keyrefs as proper nouns and don't precede them with an article.
section.note: To avoid translation errors, it may be a good idea to resolve all conrefs and keyrefsLearn how to quickly replace content references and keyword references with relevant content in oXygen XML Editor. before localizing your project.

title.ph: Importing a DITA project into memoQ

task.shortdesc: Learn how to import your DITA project into memoQ while preserving the project's folder structure.

context.p: When translating a DITA project, it is important to preserve the relationships between files. To import your project into memoQ without losing the project's folder structure, follow these steps:

step.cmd: In the New memoQ project dialog, enter the Name of the project.

image.alt: Choosing a language pair in 'New memoQ project' dialog

step.cmd: Enter the Client and any optional details, then click Next.
In the Translation memories step, choose or create a translation memory.
In the Term bases step, choose or create a term base.
Click … next to the Base path field, choose the folder where you keep your project and click OK.

image.alt: The 'Add folder structure' dialog in memoQ

step.cmd: In the Document import options dialog, remove any files you don't want to translate and click OK.

image.alt: The 'Document import options' dialog in memoQ

taskbody.result: Project files are ready for translation. DITA project imported into memoQ To export a translated project, right-click on the root folder and choose ExportExport (Stored Path).

taskbody.context: If your DITA project contains a lot of repetitive content, it may be useful to include all repetitions in one view. To create a view containing all repetitions in memoQ, follow these steps:

step.cmd: Go to Project homeTranslations and select all files.
Right-click the files and choose Create View.

image.alt: The 'Create View' option in memoQ 'Translations' screen

step.cmd: In the Create view dialog, enter the Name of the view, select Extract repetitions, and click OK.

taskbody.result: Now you can work on a view containing all repetitive segments in your project. An example memoQ view containing repetitions

glossentry.glossdef: Computer-Assisted Translation; the use of software tools (such as translation memory tools and terminology managers) to assist a human translator in the translation process.
Comma-Separated Values; a text file format that uses commas to separate values.
Darwin Information Typing Architecture; a standard XML-based architecture for creating topic-based documentation.
A popular computer-assisted translation (CAT) software suite that runs on Microsoft Windows operating systems.
A popular XML editor offering advanced features for working with DITA content.
Scalable Vector Graphics; an XML-based vector graphics format.
eXtensible Markup Language; a markup language designed to store and transport data in a format that is readable by both humans and machines.
